overview_of_class: The recent wave of immigration has brought new attention to the fact that Germany is not (and has maybe never been) a homogeneous society. At least since the 1950s, when so-called guest workers started to arrive, the concepts of "Heimat" (homeland) and being German in general have been liquefied; they have been debated and disputed ever since. From the beginning, literature plays an important role in this process of soul-searching. We will examine fiction, autobiography, poetry, and political and theoretical writings by and about "minority voices" in Germany in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Questions we will explore include: What is the relationship between autobiographical writing and identity? What is a "minority" and how might we conceive of a "minority" literature in a manner that is critical to identitarian claims of ethnicity, religious belief, gender, and class? What is the role played by "minority literature" in Germany, and how has its status changed in the last decades?
name: Minority Voices in Germany
subject: GERMAN
